comments.commentBody: The woman is insane and utterly despicable. She had no agenda save being opposed to the Communists. Now her only agenda seems to be opposing any kind of progress. Look at the kind of "reform" she introduced in Calcutta -- painting the city blue!  No sanitation or rubbish collection or industry but hey, lets pain the city blue and we'll be fine!!! And shamelessly dictatorial and paranoid -- didnt she order the arrest of a guy who lampooned her in a cartoon? What on earth possessed the Bengalis to vote her CM? The sooner she is tossed on the rubbishheap of history the better.

The "Confidence Fairy" strategy to a booming economy can trace its modern roots back to Reagan and his ability to conflate real life and movies. A common theme in movies (and Reagan speeches) is that confidence in one's ability will overcome superior opponents, natural disasters and the laws of physics. How else do we explain the success of movie heroes in outrunning explosions, dodging bullets and navigating car chases through densely populated urban neighborhoods without hitting any pedestrians? It's obviously the Confidence Fairy. Romney doesn't need a detailed plan. He just needs to hire The Expendables to create 12 million jobs and restore the economy.

Migosh, boxoffice-wise this may be the worst late summer/early autumn season in recent movie history.  Clearly no one is going to see much of anything, and it's not just the venues that I've been attending.  Are moviegoers actually beginning to discriminate between the usual trash and the unusual sewage and telling those responsible that they're no longer interested in either?  Too bad for the bare handful of decent films out there (The Master, ParaNorman, For a Good Time, Call...) which are similarly destined for box-office oblivion when the prevailing mood is one of "why bother?".

Anything is a suitable subject of study at respectable universities. That's what makes a university different from a training college.

However, there is an important point here which needs to be made. Management is not a difficult skill (I write from experience). Managers make more money than the people they manage largely because salaries are determined by managers.

Of course to get to the top in management, one needs to be bright. But that is true in almost any field. The top 10 CEOs in America are no brighter, as a group, than the top 10 engineers or medical researchers. They receive many times more money only because their buddies determine their income and because, as you state, they are greedier.

The Romney campaign, and the slobbering financial types who keep it afloat, have confirmed that "businessmen" are no brighter than nurses or electricians or librarians. They are just greedier. Perhaps this joke of a campaign will finally suggest to Americans that business administration is not a suitable subject of study at otherwise respectable universities, let alone a life pursuit that qualifies anyone for governing. Perhaps this stupid conceit -- which I concede was foisted on us by Bill Clinton and Barack Obama, too -- will finally die. But, hey, I'm an optimist.

"Poor old Mitt insanely proposing the same old republican bromides."

Yup.
Donziboy, Reagan tripled the National debt, Bush 2 doubled it and under President Obama it has risen about 50%, due to the mess he inherited.
From 2002 to 2008 the 43rd president also managed to run up the countries debt by 60% of what the 42 presidents before him ......

Oh Professor Krugman you are one funny guy.  Poor old Mitt insanely proposing the same old republican bromides, such as defeating the growing deficits by promoting private sector growth.   These of course are an obvious sign of insanity while Barack Obama's plan to spend more government money than he has managed to spend in his first term, to no measurable effect, is not insanity, merely a sign of patience, maturity, and confidence that generating historic debt will eventually pay off.  In one term the 44th President has managed to run up the countries debt by almost 60% of what the 43 Presidents before him took 200 years to do and in his next term he proposes to do it again.  This is just what the country needs Dr. Krugman along with a good dose of inflation so we can pay off our debts with cheap dollars.  Sure, that's a plan that has served Argentina well in the last 100 years. Ha!Ha!

Right on the mark re: Romney. But why the blind boosterism for Obama.

In spite of the Republican obstructionism, there are many things he has responsibility for:

1. Creating a cabinet and staff totally dominated by ties to big finance. Not one single progressive to be found. But plenty of former and future employees of Goldman, Chase, and Citi.

2. Freezing Federal workers' pay, which hurts them, hurts the economy and reinforces the very pernicious idea that "the federal government is like your family...etc etc." This misleading idea has often been presented by O.

3. Taking no significant action to protect homeowners and giving the banks a complete free pass. The Republicans were much more aggressive during the Savings and Loan scandal.

4. Keeping the entire Bush military team (Petraeus!), "surging" in Afghanistan, promising to stay till 2024!!!

5. Targeting whistle blowers, increasing surveillance, increasing military adventurism world-wide.

6. Taking part in very dangerous new "trade" agreements

I could go on....but this is all well known.

The fact that Romney is worse does not necessitate becoming a blind booster for Obama

Robert, Your remarks are essentially correct. But, we have only 2 viable candidates to choose from and the choice is clear.
Obama/Biden is the only choice.

Romney's problems among working class whites in the Midwest are not surprising when you compare the two candidates.

On one side, there is Pink Slip Mitt, who amassed a quarter-of-a-billion fortune at least in part by engaging in the type of vulture capitalism that destroyed so many middle class jobs in the heartland. Romney then hid much of that fortune in offshore investments, and refuses to release his tax records so that we would have a better idea of where and how he has invested. And to top it all off, Romney is running on a platform of raising taxes on middle class families by $2000 while eliminating their Medicare, all to pay for $4.3 trillion in tax giveaways to billionaires and big corporations. As Jennifer Granholm said "in Romney's world, the cars get the elevator and the workers get the shaft."

On the other side is President Obama, who has provided an average tax cut of $3,600 to middle class Americans and wants the wealthy to start paying their fair share again so that we can reserve programs like Medicare. He has fought to preserve middle class jobs by, among other things, rescuing the auto industry and, thereby, saving one million jobs. And, as even Bill Kristol admitted today, President Obama "did pretty well" in turning around the economic meltdown that occurred under W. Bush.

http://www.winningprogressive.org

https://www.facebook.com/pages/Winning-Progressive/195682780442236
Stay classy, Stu.

Pennsylvania-based Susquehanna Polling and Research (SP&R) is a leading survey research and political polling firm for both candidates for public office (GOP only),

ROFL

JoannaE, the problem with your analysis and attempt to paint this as like the 1980 election is that the economy was in the toilet when Bush left office. The crash happened in 2008 --- BEFORE Obama took office. The horror of the that time is behind us, the economy is slowly improving. Moreover, at least as of today, there are no American hostages in the Middle East. We do have the remnants of the wars that Bush started and which Obama is winding down. So there is no analogy.

Moreover, Romney is not Reagan. He has not given us a reason to vote for him. So the "Anybody But Obama" crowd will vote Republican regardless of who the nominee is, but the middle of the electorate, I would guess, want to know what they would be getting with a Romney presidency. I really don't understand why he won't take a position on what he would do to create jobs in the short term (he criticizes Obama but doesn't say what he would do differently other than tax cuts and smaller government), nor has he told us the tax loopholes he wants to close, nor has he told us the federal departments he will close or cut etc.
In Fl, you are not allowed to take pictures/ videos in the polls.  Against the law.  Not sure about other states.

What's WRONG with Pennsylvania? Absolutely nothing!

People understand Romney better than he hoped they would, and they know he doesn't have their best interests or the best interests of the country at heart.

Romney is for the rich and the racists. He has no other natural constituency.
Was there a point to this diatrabe and exactly what did it have to do with the story? I like the name, though, no trolling here.
Because they have been doing a state by state analysis for over 3 months? I think they already did Idaho, so you might have to search the archives.

It's not just which party controls the house, but, if it is the GOP, which members. Some of the old time members of the GOP house understand that you have to compromise to get things done. Unfortunately, most of the newer members don't understand that. Also, there is a battle between the Boeher wing and the Cantor wing of the GOP. Boehner does seem more open to compromise, but his hands have been tied.

Also important is those that have signed "the pledge." A few members who are now in the house have been walking back that pledge.

While I do hope the Dems take back the house, if they don't, we'll have to see which GOP party the Dems are up against.

you're comparing 3 different methodologies. Intrade is a betting mode, Nate's is a predictive model, and the House ofRas is just a poll. Everyone knows you ignore the House of Ras until the last 2 weeks. He floats trial balloon polls to see if he can flip the narrative, but keeps himself within a mean so he never ends up too far off in the end.
Sure Barry, not even Karl Rove agrees with you. Have a nice life.

Voter enthusiasm is very rarely as important as people want to think in presidential elections since they are consistently very high turnout. But I'm sure you'll vanish November 7th anyways so only a few more months of your nonesensical rants.

You're right about Nebraska being Republican, but not the south. There are a few things we've managed to do here that are different. We don't allow charter schools, and we don't allow tax credits for charitable donations given to private school tuition assistance funds. Both those issues come up from time to time, and thus far our legislature has voted them down. Also, I'm proud to say, our legislature did NOT enact Arizona style immigration reform - there was a bill the last session but it got voted down.

Funny you mention Ben Nelson. You're right that he mostly voted with Republicans. But ever since he voted with Democrats on health care reform people hate him. They reviled him for "the Cornhusker kickback" (which never came to fruition), but no one ever complained about any other government money that came our way. I doubt he would have been re-elected if he'd have run again.
Susquehanna is a Republican pollster.

It appears that Mr. Romney is doing everything he can to lose the election. So we will not likely find out whether his dubious claims of returning optimism will pan out. An Obama victory is little reason for optimism either, as his administration delivers empty promises in speeches while thwarting attempts by municipalities or anyone else to resolve the home mortgage morass if there is any possibility that the wildly irresponsible financial institutions suffer one dime in profits.
The window of opportunity for an appearance by the confidence fairy has been nailed shut, in large measure by an administration that absolutely refuses to prosecute the perpetrators of the largest criminal fraud scheme in history (~$12 trillion). I suppose the statute of limitations has run out on most of them crimes now anyway, how convenient for the empty suits that populate the so-called Justice Department.
Banks are not lending because, unbelievably, it is still far more profitable to gamble in the Wall Street casino with other people’s tax payer insured money, than it is to spend all that time and effort to determine if a loan recipient is viable. Banksters are merely behaving rationally given the environment they are operating in. That environment however, was created by, and is perpetuated by, the current legal and regulatory landscape. If the current leadership had any real interest in returning the economy to “normal”, a priority should be to get banks back in the business of banking.
I call foul.  You may not use the terms 'liberal Democrat' and 'balanced view.' It's quite simply a contradiction in terms.

Peter, I don't know if one could say they were "phony" polls -- real people are probably being called.

Their questions are definitely suspect and could designed to achieve the purpose you suggest. Someone posted some of the questions for one of these dodgy polls on Political Wire the other day, and there was an obvious anti-Obama bias. Questions were worded with prefaces like "given how much President Obama has weakened the United States, which candidate do you think..." and that sort of thing.

http://richardcharnin.wordpress.com/2012/08/18/perspectives-on-a-new-exi...

In the 1988-2008 presidential elections there were 274 state exit polls and 226 red-shifted to the Republican. The probability is ZERO (3.7E-31). Of the 274 polls, 126 exceeded the margin of error; only 14 would be expected to do so at the 95% confidence level. Once again, the probability is ZERO (8E-75). Of the 126 polls which exceeded the margin of error, 123 red-shifted to the Republican.The probability is ZERO (5.4E-106).

The 1988-2008 exit poll data is all here:
https://docs.google.com/spreadsheet/pub?key=0AjAk1JUWDMyRdFIzSTJtMTJZekN...
No Joanna, Nate here was the most accutate in 2008.  Keep dreaming.
